importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is a placeholder date. The actual relevant date is October 21, 2025, when the article was updated and reported on the delay of the Trump-Putin pre-meeting.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline referenced in the article indicates Trump's expectation for a Trump-Putin summit within two weeks of the call with Putin, reflecting his urgency to resolve the war in Ukraine through diplomacy.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump expressed hope for a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin, aiming to end the war in Ukraine through diplomatic means.

An anticipated pre-meeting between U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov has been delayed or postponed, due to divergent views on ending Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
The White House and senior officials believe that Lavrov is not a key decision-maker and is only loyal to Putin, limiting the effectiveness of diplomatic talks with him.
The Kremlin does not see the pre-meeting as a critical step and has not committed to a new date for the summit, stating that no date was ever set.
A possible alternative for the Rubio-Lavrov meeting is being considered at an ASEAN-led global summit in Malaysia.
Trump has consistently called for an immediate end to the war in Ukraine, emphasizing a 'battle line' solution to avoid prolonged conflict.
The previous Trump-Putin summit in Anchorage, Alaska, in the past two months, ended without a deal, highlighting the difficulty of achieving tangible outcomes in past negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the article as the driving force behind the push for a rapid diplomatic summit with Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine, emphasizing peace through a 'battle line' approach and calling for immediate cessation of hostilities.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit and represents Russia's position on the ongoing war in Ukraine, with both leaders having previously discussed a diplomatic resolution.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio is a key U.S. diplomat involved in pre-summit consultations with Russia's foreign minister, and his stance on the war in Ukraine influences whether the Trump-Putin summit proceeds.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is the Russian representative in pre-summit discussions with Rubio, but is viewed by the U.S. as being loyal to Putin and not a key decision-maker, which undermines the potential effectiveness of the diplomatic talks.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov has publicly responded to the Trump-Putin summit timeline, stating that no date was set and thus a summit cannot be postponed, reinforcing the urgency and formality of the diplomatic process.

namedEntities.name: ASEAN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ASEAN is being considered as a potential venue for a future meeting between Rubio and Lavrov, suggesting that diplomatic engagement may occur in a multilateral setting rather than a bilateral one.

namedEntities.name: Budapest, Hungary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Budapest is the proposed location for the Trump-Putin summit, indicating a significant diplomatic venue where high-level negotiations between the U.S. and Russia are expected to take place.

namedEntities.name: Anchorage, Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Anchorage was the site of the last in-person Trump-Putin summit, which ended without a deal, setting a precedent for the difficulty of achieving concrete outcomes in past negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Ukraine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ongoing war in Ukraine is the central issue driving the diplomatic efforts between Trump and Putin, with both leaders calling for an immediate end to hostilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has expressed hopes for a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine, but progress has stalled after a pre-meeting between U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov was delayed due to divergent views on ending the conflict. The White House and U.S. officials believe Lavrov is not a key decision-maker and is loyal only to Putin, making high-level diplomatic talks with him ineffective. Despite this, a possible alternative meeting between Rubio and Lavrov is being explored at a future ASEAN-led global summit in Malaysia. The Kremlin maintains that no date has been set for the summit and thus it cannot be postponed. Trump has reiterated his call for an immediate end to the war, advocating for a 'battle line' solution, while past summits, such as the one in Anchorage, have failed to produce binding agreements, highlighting the ongoing challenges in achieving peace.
title: Trump’s hope for quick second summit with Putin may be stalled as pre-meeting off for now
